channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: Ukraine Braces for Russian Attacks on War’s Anniversary
item.description: Additional security measures are being put in place in parts of the country, and schools have been advised to switch to remote learning.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times

item.title: Bulgarian Factories and Secret Task Forces: How the West Hunts for Soviet Arms
item.description: Ukraine has long relied on Russian weapons for its armed forces. Now it is scrambling to get Soviet-era ammunition for those weapons, with the help of manufacturers even in rural corners of Eastern Europe.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Justin Scheck and Boryana Dzhambazova
item.media:credit: Nikolay Doychinov for The New York Times
item.media:description: The small mountain town of Kostenets, Bulgaria, will soon start producing shells for Soviet-era artillery for use by Ukraine’s military.

item.title: Turkish Builders Come Under Intense Scrutiny Over Shoddy Construction
item.description: More than 43,000 deaths in Turkey from an earthquake have raised painful and angry questions over whether some of those fatalities could have been avoided with better building standards.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard, Elif Ince and Safak Timur
item.media:credit: Emin Ozmen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rescue workers in Adiyaman, Turkey, this month.

item.title: Want That Coffee With Olive Oil? Starbucks Thinks Italians Will.
item.description: The company has amassed an audience in Italy, and now it is betting on two very Italian ingredients.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Olive oil on display at a Starbucks in Milan on Wednesday. The company has introduced a line of coffee drinks that include olive oil, but the general population has yet to try them.

item.title: Northern Ireland Brexit Deal Is Gamble for UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak
item.description: Ever since Britain voted to leave the European Union, the question of Northern Ireland’s border has bedeviled prime ministers. Rishi Sunak’s effort to broker a deal is already under threat.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: The border between Northern Ireland and Ireland has been a thorny issue since the Brexit vote.

item.title: A Year of War in Ukraine: A Guide to the Conflict
item.description: On the first anniversary of the invasion, here’s a guide to how the biggest war in Europe since World War II came about, and what’s at stake for Russia and the world.
item.dc:creator: Eric Nagourney, Dan Bilefsky and Richard Pérez-Peña
item.media:description: A Ukrainian mortar team on the front lines in eastern Ukraine as the war approached its first anniversary.

item.title: A National Treasure on the Rise Is Hit With a Doping Allegation
item.description: A star Olympic runner from Australia was suspended over a positive drug test of a kind that critics have called alarmingly open to human error.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Peter Bol of Australia after winning the silver medal in an 800-meter race at the Commonwealth Games in Birmingham, England, last year.

item.title: More Than 50 Missing After Coal Mine Collapses in Northern China
item.description: By Thursday, four deaths had been confirmed as rescuers worked to save miners at the site in Inner Mongolia.
item.dc:creator: Chang Che and John Liu
item.media:description: Rescuers at the site of the mine collapse in the Chinese region of Inner Mongolia on Wednesday night, in an image taken from CCTV, the state broadcaster.

item.title: Ahead of Nigeria’s Election, a Cash Shortage Causes Chaos and Suffering
item.description: Nigeria’s government changed the currency design before the presidential election, causing shortages and wreaking social havoc.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean
item.media:credit: Taiwo Aina for The New York Times
item.media:description: So-called point-of-service operators stand on street corners with card machines, offering withdrawals, essentially functioning as human A.T.M.s.

item.title: Nigerian Election 2023: What to Know About Candidates and Polling So Far
item.description: The presidential election this week in Africa’s most populous country is completely unpredictable. An unexpected third candidate with a huge youth following may upend decades of traditional politics.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean
item.media:description: Candidates in the race to become Nigeria’s next president, from left: Bola Ahmed Tinubu, Atiku Abubakar, Peter Obi, Rabiu Kwankwaso.

item.title: Poland, Long Leery of Foreigners, Has Welcomed Ukrainians
item.description: The country, once one of the world’s most ethnically and culturally homogeneous, has accommodated far more refugees from neighboring Ukraine than any other nation.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Goncharuk family arrived in Wroclaw, Poland, from Kharkiv, Ukraine. They live in a single room at a former college dormitory.

item.title: Mexico Hobbles Election Agency That Helped End One-Party Rule
item.description: The changes come ahead of a presidential election next year and are part of a pattern of challenges to democratic institutions across the Western Hemisphere.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff
item.media:credit: Luis Antonio Rojas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thousands of people packed Mexico City’s Zócalo in November to support President Andrés Manuel López Obrador’s proposed electoral changes.

item.title: South Korea Inches Toward Same-Sex Equality, but Broader Bill Is Stalled
item.description: Christian conservatives in the country have campaigned tirelessly for decades to prevent legislation that would offer protections to L.G.B.T.Q. people.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:description: Seoul City Hall Plaza during a Pride event in 2022. A bill that would protect sexual minorities against discrimination has encountered fierce opposition in South Korea.

item.title: Wind and Solar Energy Projects Are Overwhelming America’s Antiquated Electrical Grids
item.description: An explosion in proposed clean energy ventures has overwhelmed the system for connecting new power sources to homes and businesses.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Walker Pickering for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pouring concrete for a wind turbine in Nebraska. More than 8,100 energy projects were waiting for permission to connect to electric grids at the end of 2021.

item.title: John Motson, BBC’s Voice of Soccer for Five Decades, Dies at 77
item.description: The broadcaster announced English soccer’s biggest moments, including 10 World Cups.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:credit: Dominic Lipinski/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: John Motson announced soccer games for the BBC for 50 years.

item.title: A Guide to the 2024 Republican Presidential Campaign
item.description: We offer a field guide to the 2024 Republican presidential campaign.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:description: Ron DeSantis, left, and Donald Trump in 2019.

item.title: Tech Leaders in Israel Wonder if It’s Time to Leave
item.description: Ahead of a judicial overhaul that could transform the country and frighten away investors, the executives of Start-Up Nation are mulling an exodus.
item.dc:creator: David Segal
item.media:credit: Ofir Berman for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Given the atmosphere now, it’s almost irresponsible to start a company” in Israel, said Yanki Margalit, a veteran entrepreneur.

item.title: Yellen Calls for More Ukraine Support and Warns China Against Helping Russia
item.description: Ahead of a meeting of G20 finance ministers, the Treasury secretary offered a dark assessment of Russia’s economy and warned China of the consequences of helping Moscow skirt U.S. sanctions.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: Janet Yellen, the Treasury secretary, offered a dark assessment of Russia’s economy, arguing that Western sanctions were working.

item.title: Global Declines in Maternal Mortality Have Stalled
item.description: Death rates in the United States have increased in recent years, as they have in Europe, the W.H.O. reported.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: A pregnant woman with Covid on her way to a hospital in Senegal. While the pandemic may have contributed to maternal deaths, experts said that didn’t fully explain trends that predated its onset.

item.title: Putin and Biden Shore Up Alliances in Dueling Appearances
item.description: On the surface, it looked like a reversion to the Cold War era. The reality was even more complicated.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear, David E. Sanger and Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: President Biden with President Klaus Iohannis of Romania on Wednesday at a gathering of NATO leaders from Eastern Europe.

item.title: In a Celebration of War, Moscow Displays, and Demands, Unity
item.description: A concert and rally in Russia’s largest stadium romanticized the invasion of Ukraine, as Vladimir V. Putin and his government seek to normalize the country’s war footing.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Nanna Heitmann
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin speaking during the rally on Wednesday at Luzhniki Stadium in Moscow.

item.title: Supreme Court Wrestles With Suit Claiming Twitter Aided Terrorists
item.description: The case, arising from an attack in Istanbul, was a companion to a case argued a day before that tested a shield for technology platforms.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: The Supreme Court heard arguments on Wednesday in a case involving a federal law that allows suits for “knowingly providing substantial assistance” to terrorists.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Key Meetings for Biden and Putin
item.description: Also, another deadly Israeli raid in the West Bank and South Korea’s fight over L.G.B.T.Q. rights.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: In this photograph, provided by Russian state media, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia is meeting with Wang Yi, China’s top foreign policy official, at the Kremlin in Moscow on Wednesday.

item.title: Ukraine Hits Russian Positions Deep Behind Enemy Lines
item.description: Nearly a dozen explosions rang out in the Russian-held Ukrainian port city of Mariupol, site of one of the best-known battles of the war.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Apartment blocks destroyed earlier in the war in Mariupol, Ukraine.

item.title: Glória Maria, Who Broke Barriers in Brazilian Television, Dies at 73
item.description: Thought to be Brazil’s first Black TV journalist and a rare female anchor, she was a trailblazer in a country with a long history of racism.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.media:credit: Ramon Vasconcelos/Agence France-Presse, via Globo TV
item.media:description: The Brazilian television journalist Glória Maria at the Globo television studio in Rio de Janeiro in 2018. She became a TV star at a time when anchor chairs in Brazil were mostly filled by white men.

item.title: Teacher in France Dies After Student Stabs Her, Government Says
item.description: A spokesman said a 16-year-old stabbed a teacher, who then died. A local prosecutor said his office had opened an investigation and the student was in custody.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter and Tom Nouvian
item.media:description: A police officer near a high school in Saint-Jean-de-Luz, France, where a student stabbed a teacher on Wednesday.

item.title: Counting votes and cutting violence
item.description: A new study found that the type of party that won election in Brazil seemed to have a correlation with violence immediately after the vote.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shattered glass at Brazil’s Supreme Court after supporters of former President Jair Bolsonaro rioted in Brasília in January.

item.title: Ukraine Prepares for Possibility of Russian Aggression via Moldova and Belarus
item.description: Military analysts doubt Russia’s ability to sustain a new front, but Ukrainian and Western officials have warned that Moscow could try to divert Ukrainian resources.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers looked out from trenches in northern Ukraine, only a few miles away from the Belarusian border, last month.

item.title: ‘Tirailleurs’: Movie Honors the African Soldiers France Tried to Forget
item.description: The success of “Tirailleurs,” set in the mire and mayhem of World War I, has helped resurface the often neglected story of colonial soldiers forced to take up somebody else’s fight.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: Omar Sy, top, and Alassane Diong in “Tirailleurs.” (The movie is called “Father and Soldier” in the United States.)

item.title: At Least 10 Palestinians Killed During Israeli Raid in West Bank
item.description: An hourslong gunfight broke out between Israeli soldiers and Palestinian gunmen during an Israeli operation to arrest Palestinian fighters. The violence left the region braced for further unrest.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: The West Bank city of Nablus on Wednesday. Hamas, the Islamist group that controls the Gaza Strip, warned that the killings would not pass “without a response.”

item.title: U.K. Court Upholds Ruling Stripping Shamima Begum’s Citizenship
item.description: Ms. Begum was one of three teenage girls from London who traveled to Syria in 2015 to join the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Shamima Begum left Britain when she was 15. Her lawyers said that she was smuggled into Syria for sexual exploitation.

item.title: Joshua Bell’s London
item.description: The celebrated violinist recommends five spots in Britain’s capital, a city he’s visited some 70 times since the 1980s.
item.dc:creator: Danielle Pergament and Mary Turner
item.media:description: Dusk falls over London’s Royal Albert Hall, where Joshua Bell has performed at the famous Proms concerts.

item.title: China’s Economic Support for Russia Could Elicit More Sanctions
item.description: U.S. officials pledged to crack down on shipments to Russia that can be used for both civilian and military purposes, but that has proved hard to police.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:description: President Biden with Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, in Kyiv. Mr. Biden said the United States and its partners would announce new measures targeting sanctions evasion this week.

item.title: Inside Taiwanese Chip Giant, a U.S. Expansion Stokes Tensions
item.description: Employee doubts are rising about Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company’s $40 billion investment in an Arizona factory.
item.dc:creator: John Liu and Paul Mozur
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company is upgrading and expanding a factory it is building in Phoenix, a vital project for U.S. tech strategy.

item.title: Biden’s Meeting With Eastern European Leaders Will Cap His Trip
item.description: The nine countries along NATO’s eastern flank are the likeliest targets of another Russian invasion.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: President Biden during a bilateral meeting on Tuesday, with President Andrzej Duda of Poland, at the Presidential Palace in Warsaw, Poland, on Tuesday.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Addresses by President Biden and Vladimir Putin.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: U.S. President Joe Biden in Warsaw, Poland on Tuesday.

item.title: How Widespread Are Forever Chemicals? They’re Everywhere.
item.description: Researchers created a map showing where PFAS compounds, linked to cancer in humans, have been detected in wildlife. It spans the globe.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn
item.media:credit: Drew YoungeDyke/National Wildlife Federation, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A warning to hunters in Oscoda, Mich.

item.title: Biden Accuses Putin of Atrocities and Urges World to Rebuke Him
item.description: In sharply opposed speeches, President Biden said Vladimir V. Putin bore sole responsibility for the war, while Mr. Putin said Russia had invaded in self-defense. But they agreed the war would not end soon.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Michael D. Shear and Anton Troianovski
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: President Biden speaking at the Royal Castle Gardens in Warsaw on Tuesday.

item.title: Italy’s Giorgia Meloni Condemns Russia and Pledges Further Support to Ukraine
item.description: The prime minister, Giorgia Meloni, reiterated her backing amid dissension within her coalition government on the issue.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni of Italy at a joint news briefing with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine on Tuesday in Kyiv.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Biden and Putin Speak on Ukraine
item.description: Also, Saudi Arabia intensifies a crackdown and the Philippines moves closer to the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: President Biden delivered remarks on Tuesday at the Royal Castle in Warsaw ahead of the anniversary of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

item.title: Judge Rejects Bid by Sept. 11 Families to Seize Frozen Afghan Central Bank Funds
item.description: A lawyer for the lead group of victim relatives who had sought $3.5 billion in frozen assets said they would appeal.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: Federal Reserve Bank of New York
item.media:description: The September 11 Memorial in New York City.

item.title: Mexico’s Ex-Top Security Official Is Convicted of Cartel Bribery
item.description: A Brooklyn jury found Genaro García Luna guilty of taking millions of dollars from the Sinaloa drug cartel when he was in charge of Mexico’s bloody war on organized crime.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer and Nate Schweber
item.media:description: Genaro García Luna in 2004, when he headed Mexico’s version of the F.B.I.

item.title: Mpox Often Leads to Severe Illness, Even Death, in People With Advanced H.I.V.
item.description: The death rate among these patients is about 15 percent, researchers reported. The virus should be added to the list of opportunistic infections seen in patients with advanced H.I.V., scientists said.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A colorized transmission electron micrograph of mpox particles, in red, in an infected cell. Although the number of cases has slowed in most regions, mpox has so far affected roughly 86,000 people in 110 countries and killed 92.

item.title: Israel Unlikely to Extradite Mexico’s Ex-Official Wanted Over Missing Students
item.description: The Mexican authorities say Tomás Zerón tortured witnesses and tampered with evidence in a crucial investigation into the 2014 disappearance of 43 students.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman and Natalie Kitroeff
item.media:description: Tomás Zerón, then the director of Mexico’s Criminal Investigation Agency, in 2015.

item.title: Poland’s Prime Minister Says His Country Was Right About Russia
item.description: Having been proved right about Russia, Warsaw is savoring its newfound influence in NATO and on Ukraine policy.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: President Biden, who praised Poland on Tuesday as “critical” in the West’s response to Russia, at a meeting with President Andrzej Duda and Prime Minister Mateusz Morawiecki in Warsaw on Tuesday.

item.title: China Tries to Mend Europe Ties Without Distancing Itself From Russia
item.description: Beijing, in urgent need of reviving its economy, wants to mend ties with Europe but is struggling to create distance between itself and Moscow.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.media:description: Wang Yi, China’s most senior diplomat, shakes hands with German Chancellor Olaf Scholz at the Munich Security Conference on Friday.

item.title: Parched California Misses a Chance to Store More Rain Underground
item.description: Torrential rains could have helped to replenish depleted aquifers, but some say state bureaucracy, designed to distribute water fairly, has stood in the way.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.category: California State Water Resources Control Board
item.media:description: The overflowing Russian River in mid-January. Next time there’s a storm, a group of vineyards and local agencies hopes to capture more floodwater.

item.title: China’s Leading Electric Carmaker Has Arrived in Germany
item.description: BYD is a powerhouse in China and sells the most electric vehicles of any company in the world. Now it has a plan to attract buyers in Europe’s largest economy.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Felix Schmitt for The New York Times
item.media:description: BYD’s Atto-3 electric sport utility vehicle in Frankfurt. So far, the vast majority of BYD cars are sold in China. But the company is looking to expand, particularly in Germany.

item.title: Wagner Group Chief Accuses Russian Military Command of Treason
item.description: Caustic accusations by the head of the Wagner mercenary group, Yevgeny Prigozhin, suggest that his vaunted access to Vladimir Putin may be on the wane.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Funeral rites for eight Wagner soldiers killed in battle this month.

item.title: What Putin’s Suspension of New START Treaty Means for Nuclear Arms Control
item.description: Mutual inspections were interrupted by the pandemic, then by the war in Ukraine. But now New START, the last nuclear agreement between Russia and the United States, is dying, and arms control may be, too.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: A Russian ballistic missile during a Moscow parade rehearsal in 2021. The New START agreement restricts each side to 1,550 nuclear weapons.

item.title: 1923: Blaze Destroys Army Buildings
item.description: The fire gutted orderly rooms and stores of the Fifth Division.
item.dc:creator: The International Herald Tribune

item.title: After Another Earthquake, Turkey Rescue Workers Push On
item.description: In the third week of a grueling effort, emergency workers battle exhaustion as the hope of finding more earthquake survivors dwindles. A powerful new quake has complicated their task.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Emin Ozmen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers, volunteers and rescue workers at the scene of a collapsed building in Antakya, Turkey, on Monday.

item.title: A Sudden Rush to Make Sustainable Aviation Fuel Mainstream
item.description: United Airlines and other companies have started a $100 million fund to invest in jet fuel that produces fewer greenhouse gases.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.media:description: Aircraft at San Francisco International Airport in 2021. Making sustainable aviation fuel mainstream will be difficult and costly to achieve.

item.title: Lives We Can Save
item.description: The opioid crisis doesn’t need to be this bad. It’s another example of America’s surprising resistance to effective treatments
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:description: Packets of buprenorphine.

item.title: In Northern Ukraine, a Different Sort of War Game
item.description: Russian forces are shelling border areas there to tie up thousands of Ukrainian troops that might otherwise defend against attacks farther south.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers at a position near the border with Russia this month. Ukrainian officials say Russia is tying down their troops in the region to keep them from battlefields farther south.

item.title: ‘Equality of Injustice for All’: Saudi Arabia Expands Crackdown on Dissent
item.description: The kingdom’s courts are meting out harsher punishments than ever to citizens who criticize the government, with prosecutions built on Twitter posts ending in prison sentences of 15 to 45 years.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ibrahim Almadi’s father, Saad, was jailed for 19 years.

item.title: Ridge Alkonis Prison Sentence Strains U.S.-Japan Relations
item.description: Lt. Ridge Alkonis was sentenced to three years after causing a deadly traffic accident in 2021. The case has irritated U.S. relations with a crucial military ally.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Hisako Ueno
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
